title: 103_hr3390
content:
The Secretary of Education is authorized to provide grants to elementary schools affected by conflict and violence for conflict resolution and mediation programs. A model project for conflict resolution must be developed within 90 days. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1994, with additional funding for subsequent years. Grants will be used to develop programs for conflict resolution and mediation for students, teachers, and school personnel in regular contact with students. Eligible applicants include local elementary schools. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a local elementary school must submit an application to the Secretary with specific information. The application must include a request for funds, details about the school and communities to be served, statistical information on conflict and violence, and assurances that federal funds will supplement non-federal funds. Each application for a grant under this Act must include a comprehensive plan detailing conflict and violence issues in the targeted elementary school and community, available resources, and a system to prevent and reduce ongoing problems. SEC. 6. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS; LIMITATIONS ON GRANTS. The Secretary can use up to 5% of funds for administration. Grants can be renewed for up to 2 years if funds were used as required and if additional funding is needed for violence prevention programs. SEC. 7. AWARD OF GRANTS. SEC. 7. AWARD OF GRANTS. The Secretary considers violence problem, need, ability, and student population in awarding grants to elementary schools. Geographic distribution is also a factor. SEC. 8. REPORTS.

Local elementary schools receiving funds must submit a detailed progress report by March 1 each year. The Secretary must also provide a report to Congress by October 1, detailing grant awards, recipient activities, statistical information, and program evaluations.

SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS.

Definitions for "local educational agency" and "Secretary" are provided in this Act.
